page.title: 12Flora- Nature Reserve (Wyre)
page.content: The age of this ancient woodland is indicated by the presence of the wild Service,Gean (or wild Cherry) and Yew trees. It is unusual for its wide range of species, some very rare. The soil is acid and the climate is such that examples of flora from both North and South are present. Sessile Oak and Wood Cranesbill mingle with Pedunc- ulate Oak and Alder Blackthorn.The trees are mainly Oak and Birch, while the understorey includes Hazel and Guelder Rose. Rare Small-leaved Lime grows along the banks of Dowles Brook. Among the rarer flowering plants: Long-leaved Helleborine, Aquilegia, Autumn Crocus, Green-winged Orchid, Dog's Mercury, and Wood Anemone. Adder's-tongue Fern can be found and the damp shaded valleys provide an ideal environment for a wide range of mosses and lichens, some very rare.
